title: Effect of Repetition Duration During Resistance Training on Muscle Hypertrophy: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
authors: Schoenfeld BJ; Ogborn DI; Krieger JW
main_tags: resistance_training; repetition_tempo; repetition_duration; hypertrophy; systematic_review; meta_analysis
notes: Hypertrophy outcomes are similar with repetition durations ~0.5–8 s/rep when training to failure; very slow tempos (>10 s/rep) appear inferior for hypertrophy, though controlled data are limited.

title: A Systematic Review with Meta-Analysis of the Effect of Resistance Training on Whole-Body Muscle Growth in Healthy Adult Males
authors: Benito PJ; Cupeiro R; Rubio-Arias JÁ; Ramos-Campo DJ; Alcaraz PE
main_tags: resistance_training; whole_body_hypertrophy; fat_free_mass; lean_mass; skeletal_muscle_mass; meta_analysis
notes: RT increases whole-body muscle mass by ~1.5 kg on average; participant characteristics explained little variance, whereas very high sets per workout showed a small negative association with gains.

title: Comparison of Periodized and Non-Periodized Resistance Training on Maximal Strength: A Meta-Analysis
authors: Williams TD; Tolusso DV; Fedewa MV; Esco MR
outcome_types: strength (1RM squat; bench_press; leg_press); limited hypertrophy reporting
notes: Periodized RT provides small-to-moderate advantages over non-periodized RT for maximal strength; hypertrophy outcomes are less frequently reported and show no large differences once volume is similar.

title: Partial Vs Full Range of Motion Resistance Training: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
authors: Wolf M; Androulakis-Korakakis P; Fisher JP; Schoenfeld BJ; Steele J
main_tags: resistance_training; range_of_motion; partial_ROM; full_ROM; hypertrophy; strength; meta_analysis
outcome_types: hypertrophy (muscle_thickness; CSA; volume); strength (1RM; isometric; dynamic)
notes: Full ROM generally produces equal or slightly greater hypertrophy and strength across the joint angle; partial ROM can give angle-specific strength benefits. Both can be effective tools depending on goal.

title: A Meta-Analysis of Resistance Training in Female Youth: Its Effect on Muscular Strength, and Shortcomings in the Literature
authors: Moran J; Sandercock G; Ramirez-Campillo R; Clark CCT; Fernandes JFT; Drury B
outcome_types: primarily strength (1RM; field_strength tests); limited hypertrophy outcomes
notes: RT is clearly effective for improving strength in female youth; hypertrophy data are sparse but suggest some gains. Highlights major shortcomings in study design/reporting for this population.

title: Effects of Resistance Training Frequency on Measures of Muscle Hypertrophy: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
authors: Schoenfeld BJ; Ogborn D; Krieger JW
outcome_types: hypertrophy (muscle_size via imaging; circumference; biopsy; densitometry)
notes: When total volume is equated, training frequency per se has only a modest effect on hypertrophy; higher frequency mainly helps by distributing or increasing weekly volume.

title: Resistance Training Load Effects on Muscle Hypertrophy and Strength Gain: Systematic Review and Network Meta-analysis
authors: Lopez P; Radaelli R; Taaffe DR; Newton RU; Galvão DA; Trajano GS; Teodoro JL; Kraemer WJ; Häkkinen K; Pinto RS
main_tags: resistance_training; load; intensity; low_load; high_load; hypertrophy; strength; network_meta_analysis
notes: Hypertrophy gains are broadly similar across low–high loads when sets are taken to or near failure; high loads provide superior maximal strength.

title: Muscle Hypertrophy and Strength Gains After Resistance Training with Different Volume-Matched Loads: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis
authors: Carvalho L; Moriggi Junior R; Barreira J; Schoenfeld BJ; Orazem J; Barroso R
main_tags: resistance_training; load; volume_matched; low_load; high_load; hypertrophy; strength; meta_analysis
notes: With volume matched, low- and high-load RT to (or near) failure produce similar hypertrophy; strength adaptations favour higher loads.

title: Strength and Hypertrophy Adaptations Between Low- vs. High-Load Resistance Training: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis
authors: Schoenfeld BJ; Grgic J; Ogborn D; Krieger JW
main_tags: resistance_training; load; low_load; high_load; hypertrophy; strength; meta_analysis
notes: Across 21 studies, hypertrophy is similar between low- and high-load RT when volume and effort are similar; strength gains favour high loads.

title: How Many Times per Week Should a Muscle Be Trained to Maximize Muscle Hypertrophy? A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis of Studies Examining the Effects of Resistance Training Frequency
authors: Schoenfeld BJ; Grgic J; Krieger J
notes: Per-muscle training frequency ≥2×/week tends to produce more hypertrophy than 1×/week when volume isn’t strictly equated; with volume equated, frequency has a smaller independent effect.

title: Does Aerobic Training Promote the Same Skeletal Muscle Hypertrophy as Resistance Training? A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
authors: Grgic J; McIlvenna LC; Fyfe JJ; Sabol F; Bishop DJ; Schoenfeld BJ; Pedisic Z
notes: RT is clearly superior to aerobic training alone for hypertrophy at both whole-muscle and fibre levels; endurance training produces smaller size gains.

title: Resistance Training Prescription for Muscle Strength and Hypertrophy in Healthy Adults: A Systematic Review and Bayesian Network Meta-analysis
authors: Currier BS; McLeod JC; Banfield L; Beyene J; Welton NJ; D’Souza AC; Keogh JAJ; Lin L; Coletta G; Yang A; Colenso-Semple L; Lau KJ; Verboom A; Phillips SM
main_tags: resistance_training; prescription; load; sets; frequency; hypertrophy; strength; network_meta_analysis
notes: All RT prescriptions outperform non-exercise control. Moderate–heavy loads and multiple sets per exercise with sufficient weekly volume rank best for hypertrophy and strength; several “good enough” configurations exist.

title: Influence of Resistance Training Proximity-to-Failure on Skeletal Muscle Hypertrophy: A Systematic Review with Meta-analysis
authors: Refalo MC; Helms ER; Trexler ET; Hamilton DL; Fyfe JJ
main_tags: resistance_training; proximity_to_failure; momentary_failure; velocity_loss; hypertrophy; meta_analysis
notes: Training very close to or to failure does not clearly outperform stopping slightly short when volume is matched; moderate proximity to failure appears sufficient for hypertrophy, especially with moderate/high loads.

title: The Effect of Resistance Training in Women on Dynamic Strength and Muscular Hypertrophy: A Systematic Review with Meta-analysis
authors: Hagstrom AD; Marshall PW; Halaki M; Hackett DA
notes: Women gain substantial strength and hypertrophy from RT; effect sizes are comparable to general (mixed-sex) literature, supporting similar programming principles for women.

title: The Compatibility of Concurrent High Intensity Interval Training and Resistance Training for Muscular Strength and Hypertrophy: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis
authors: Sabag A; Najafi A; Michael S; Esgin T; Halaki M; Hackett D
main_tags: concurrent_training; high_intensity_interval_training; resistance_training; hypertrophy; strength; meta_analysis
notes: Concurrent RT + HIIT generally does not meaningfully impair hypertrophy when programmed sensibly; small negative effects on strength are possible with high HIIT doses or poor scheduling.

title: Effects of Periodization on Strength and Muscle Hypertrophy in Volume-Equated Resistance Training Programs: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis
authors: Moesgaard L; Beck MM; Christiansen L; Aagaard P; Lundbye-Jensen J
main_tags: resistance_training; periodization; linear_periodization; undulating_periodization; hypertrophy; strength; meta_analysis
notes: When total volume is equated, periodized and non-periodized RT show similar hypertrophy; periodization gives a small advantage for strength in some comparisons.

title: Muscular Adaptations in Low- Versus High-Load Resistance Training: A Meta-analysis
authors: Schoenfeld BJ; Wilson JM; Lowery RP; Krieger JW
main_tags: resistance_training; load; low_load; high_load; hypertrophy; strength; meta_analysis
notes: Low-load (≤60% 1RM) and high-load (>60% 1RM) RT to failure produce similar hypertrophy; high loads yield greater maximal strength.

title: Dose-Response Relationship Between Weekly Resistance Training Volume and Increases in Muscle Mass: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis
authors: Schoenfeld BJ; Ogborn D; Krieger JW
main_tags: resistance_training; training_volume; weekly_sets; dose_response; hypertrophy; meta_analysis
notes: Higher weekly set volume per muscle is associated with greater hypertrophy up to a point (low < moderate < higher volumes), with diminishing returns at very high volumes.

title: A Systematic Review, Meta-analysis and Meta-regression of the Effect of Protein Supplementation on Resistance Training-induced Gains in Muscle Mass and Strength in Healthy Adults
authors: Morton RW; Murphy KT; McKellar SR; Schoenfeld BJ; Henselmans M; Helms E; Aragon AA; Devries MC; Banfield L; Krieger JW; Phillips SM
main_tags: protein_supplementation; resistance_training; hypertrophy; strength; nutrition; meta_analysis
notes: Protein supplementation on top of RT yields small but meaningful additional gains in lean mass and strength, especially when baseline protein intake is lower and/or in untrained individuals.

title: Effect of Resistance Training Frequency on Gains in Muscular Strength: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
authors: Grgic J; Schoenfeld BJ; Davies TB; Lazinica B; Krieger JW; Pedisic Z
notes: When volume is equated, training frequency has minimal independent effect on strength; higher frequencies help mainly via enabling more total quality work and better fatigue management.

title: Efficacy of Resistance Training in Hypoxia on Muscle Hypertrophy and Strength Development: A Systematic Review with Meta-analysis
authors: Benavente C; Schoenfeld BJ; Padial P; Feriche B
training_status: meta-analysis (healthy adults; hypoxic vs normoxic RT)
main_tags: resistance_training; hypoxia; hypoxic_training; hypertrophy; strength; meta_analysis
notes: Overall hypertrophy and strength gains are similar between RT in hypoxia and normoxia; some protocols show small extra hypertrophy benefits under hypoxia.

title: Effects of Resistance Training on Muscle Size and Strength in Very Elderly Adults: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis of Randomized Controlled Trials
authors: Grgic J; Garofolini A; Orazem J; Sabol F; Schoenfeld BJ; Pedisic Z
main_tags: resistance_training; very_elderly; sarcopenia; hypertrophy; strength; meta_analysis
notes: Very elderly adults still gain meaningful muscle size, strength, and functional capacity from RT; supports RT as a key intervention against age-related decline.

title: Effects of Resistance Training with Moderate vs Heavy Loads on Muscle Mass and Strength in the Elderly: A Meta-analysis
main_tags: resistance_training; load; moderate_load; heavy_load; elderly; hypertrophy; strength; meta_analysis
notes: In elderly individuals, heavy-load RT tends to produce somewhat greater strength gains; hypertrophy differences between moderate and heavy loads are smaller, especially when total work is matched.

title: Sex Differences in Resistance Training: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
authors: Roberts BM; Nuckols G; Krieger JW
main_tags: resistance_training; sex_differences; males_vs_females; hypertrophy; strength; meta_analysis
notes: No meaningful sex differences in hypertrophy responses to RT; strength gains are broadly similar between sexes when programs are matched, with some small relative differences by region.

title: The Efficacy of Resistance Training in Hypoxia to Enhance Strength and Muscle Growth: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis
authors: Ramos-Campo DJ; Scott BR; Alcaraz PE; Rubio-Arias JA
training_status: meta-analysis (healthy adults; hypoxic vs normoxic RT)
main_tags: resistance_training; hypoxia; blood_flow_restriction_style; hypertrophy; strength; meta_analysis
notes: Similar overall strength and hypertrophy between hypoxic and normoxic RT; some protocols show small advantages for hypoxia. (Benavente 2023 provides updated estimates.)

title: The Effects of Low-Load vs. High-Load Resistance Training on Muscle Fiber Hypertrophy: A Meta-Analysis
main_tags: resistance_training; load; low_load; high_load; muscle_fiber_hypertrophy; type_I; type_II; meta_analysis
notes: Low- and high-load RT to failure produce broadly similar fibre-level hypertrophy; high loads may have slight advantages for type II fibres, but differences are small.

title: Magnitude of Muscle Strength and Mass Adaptations Between High-Load Resistance Training Versus Low-Load Resistance Training Associated with Blood-Flow Restriction: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
authors: Lixandrao ME; Ugrinowitsch C; Berton R; Vechin FC; Conceição MS; Damas F; Libardi CA; Roschel H
main_tags: resistance_training; blood_flow_restriction; low_load; high_load; hypertrophy; strength; meta_analysis
notes: Low-load BFR-RT can induce hypertrophy comparable to traditional high-load RT, but strength gains still favour high-load training.

title: A Systematic Review of the Effects of Different Resistance Training Volumes on Muscle Hypertrophy
authors: Baz-Valle E; Balsalobre-Fernández C; Alix-Fages C; Santos-Concejero J
main_tags: resistance_training; training_volume; weekly_sets; hypertrophy; trained_individuals; meta_analysis
notes: In trained lifters, higher set volumes generally yield greater hypertrophy than low volumes, but with diminishing returns; extremely high volumes are not clearly superior.

title: Single vs. Multiple Sets of Resistance Exercise for Muscle Hypertrophy: A Meta-Analysis
main_tags: resistance_training; training_volume; single_set; multiple_sets; hypertrophy; dose_response; meta_analysis
notes: Multiple sets per exercise produce significantly greater hypertrophy than single sets; 2–3 sets per exercise clearly outperform 1 set, with possible added benefit up to ~4–6 sets.

title: Influence of Resistance Training Load on Measures of Skeletal Muscle Hypertrophy and Improvements in Maximal Strength and Neuromuscular Task Performance: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis
authors: Refalo MC; Hamilton DL; Paval DR; Gallagher IJ; Feros SA; Fyfe JJ
main_tags: resistance_training; load; hypertrophy; strength; neuromuscular_performance; meta_analysis
notes: Hypertrophy is similar across a wide range of loads when training near failure; higher loads confer advantages for maximal strength and some neuromuscular performance tasks.

title: Potential Moderators of the Effects of Blood Flow Restriction Training on Muscle Strength and Hypertrophy: A Meta-analysis Based on a Comparison with High-Load Resistance Training
authors: Geng Y; Wu X; Zhang Y; Zhang M
main_tags: resistance_training; blood_flow_restriction; moderators; hypertrophy; strength; meta_analysis
notes: BFR-RT is broadly comparable to high-load RT for hypertrophy and somewhat inferior for strength; moderator analyses highlight the role of load, cuff pressure, rest intervals, and program length.

title: The Effects of Eccentric Versus Concentric Resistance Training on Muscle Strength and Mass
main_tags: resistance_training; eccentric_training; concentric_training; hypertrophy; strength; systematic_review
notes: Both eccentric- and concentric-focused RT increase strength and muscle mass; eccentric-emphasized training often yields equal or slightly greater hypertrophy and eccentric strength, but both modes are effective.

title: Effects of Range of Motion on Resistance Training Adaptations: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis
authors: Pallarés JG; Hernández-Belmonte A; Martínez-Cava A; Vetrovsky T; Steffl M; Courel-Ibáñez J
main_tags: resistance_training; range_of_motion; full_ROM; partial_ROM; hypertrophy; strength; meta_analysis
notes: Full ROM tends to yield greater overall hypertrophy and strength across the joint ROM; partial ROM gives joint-angle-specific strength gains and can still be a useful tool.

title: Effects of Resistance Training Volume on Physical Function, Lean Body Mass and Lower-Body Muscle Hypertrophy and Strength in Older Adults: A Systematic Review and Network Meta-analysis of 151 Randomised Trials
authors: Radaelli R; Rech A; Molinari T; Markarian AM; Petropoulou M; Granacher U; Hortobágyi T; Lopez P
main_tags: resistance_training; training_volume; older_adults; hypertrophy; strength; physical_function; network_meta_analysis
notes: Moderate RT volumes are sufficient to meaningfully improve strength, hypertrophy, and function in older adults; higher volumes may add benefit but with diminishing returns and greater burden.

title: Is Power Training Effective to Produce Muscle Hypertrophy in Older Adults? A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis
authors: Bet da Rosa Orssatto L; Bezerra E; Shield A; Trajano GS
main_tags: power_training; older_adults; hypertrophy; strength; rate_of_force_development; meta_analysis
notes: Power-oriented RT (lighter loads, fast intent) can still produce meaningful hypertrophy and strength gains in older adults, alongside improvements in functional power.

title: Relative Protein Intake and Physical Function in Older Adults: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis of Observational Studies
outcome_types: physical_function (gait speed, chair rise, balance); strength; body_comp (lean-mass-related proxies)
notes: Higher relative protein intake in older adults is associated with better physical function and lower disability risk.

title: Effects of Protein Supplementation on Body Composition, Physiological Adaptations, and Performance During Endurance Training: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
outcome_types: body_comp (FFM, FM); performance (VO₂max, time trial, time to exhaustion); strength (secondary)
notes: Protein supplementation during endurance training produces small benefits for lean mass and modest improvements in some endurance performance outcomes. (Wiley Online Library)

title: Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis of Protein Intake to Support Muscle Mass and Function in Healthy Adults
outcome_types: body_comp (FFM, LBM); strength (1RM, MVC); physical_function (chair rise, walking tests)
notes: In healthy adults, higher protein intakes (especially ≥1.2 g/kg/d) better support gains or preservation of muscle mass and function versus lower intakes. (Experts at Arizona)

title: Dietary Protein Intake Above the Current RDA and Bone Health: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis of Randomized Controlled Trials
notes: Protein intakes modestly above the RDA do not harm bone and may slightly benefit BMD when calcium/vitamin D are adequate. (Frontiers)

title: Effects of Dietary Protein Intake on Body Composition Changes After Weight Loss in Older Adults: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
notes: Higher protein intake during weight-loss interventions helps attenuate fat-free mass loss in older adults compared with lower-protein diets. (PubMed)

title: A Critical Examination of Dietary Protein Requirements, Benefits, and Excesses in Strength Athletes
notes: Reviews evidence that strength athletes likely benefit from protein intakes around 1.6–2.2 g/kg/d for maximising RT adaptations, with little evidence of harm from higher intakes in healthy people.

title: The Effect of Protein Timing on Muscle Strength and Hypertrophy: A Meta-Analysis
authors: Schoenfeld BJ, Aragon AA, Krieger JW
notes: When total daily protein is sufficient, specific timing around workouts has little extra effect on RT-induced hypertrophy or strength. (PubMed)

title: Dose–Response Relationship Between Protein Intake and Muscle Mass Increase: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis of Randomized Controlled Trials
notes: Protein intakes up to about 1.3–1.6 g/kg/d enhance lean mass versus lower intakes, with diminishing returns beyond this range.

title: The Impact of Protein Quality on the Promotion of Resistance-Training-Induced Changes in Muscle Mass
notes: Argues that rapidly digested, leucine-rich proteins (e.g. whey/dairy) may better support RT-induced hypertrophy than some lower-quality proteins when total intake is matched.

title: Effects of Higher- Versus Lower-Protein Diets on Health Outcomes: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
outcome_types: body_weight; body_comp (FFM, FM); lipids; blood_pressure; glycaemic_markers
notes: High-protein diets give slightly greater weight/fat loss and modest cardiometabolic improvements vs. lower-protein diets, with no major short-term safety concerns.

title: Dietary Protein to Maximize Resistance Training: A Review and Examination of Protein Spread and Change Theories
notes: Critically examines “protein spread” and “protein change” ideas; emphasizes total daily protein (~1.3–1.8 g/kg/d) as the main driver of RT adaptations.

title: Synergistic Effect of Increased Total Protein Intake and Resistance Training on Muscle Strength: A Dose–Response Meta-Analysis of Randomized Controlled Trials
notes: Higher total protein during RT (up to ~1.5–1.6 g/kg/d) enhances strength gains vs. lower intakes, with limited extra benefit above that range.

title: Dietary Protein and Bone Health Across the Life-Course: An Updated Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis Over 40 Years
notes: Across the lifespan, higher protein intakes generally support, rather than harm, bone health when calcium and vitamin D are adequate.

title: The Effects of Protein Supplements on Muscle Mass, Strength, and Aerobic and Anaerobic Power in Healthy Adults: A Systematic Review
notes: Protein supplements add small benefits for lean mass and strength when combined with training, especially if baseline protein intake is suboptimal.

title: Effects of Protein Supplements Consumed With Meals Versus Between Meals on Resistance Training–Induced Body Composition Changes in Adults
notes: With the same protein dose, taking protein with meals favored greater fat-mass loss, while between meals slightly favored lean-mass gain.

title: Is Protein the Forgotten Ingredient: Effects of Higher Compared to Lower Protein Diets on Cardiometabolic Risk Factors – A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis of Randomised Controlled Trials
outcome_types: body_weight; BMI; waist_circumference; FM; blood_lipids; blood_pressure; glucose/insulin; HbA1c
notes: Higher-protein diets show small but favourable effects on weight/fat loss, systolic BP, some lipids, TAG and insulin compared with lower-protein diets.

title: Effect of Plant Versus Animal Protein on Muscle Mass, Strength, Physical Performance, and Sarcopenia: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis of Randomized Controlled Trials
outcome_types: body_comp (FFM, muscle_mass); strength (handgrip, 1RM); physical_performance (gait speed, chair rise); sarcopenia_status
notes: When total protein is matched, plant and animal proteins have broadly similar effects on muscle mass, strength and performance in adults.

title: Dietary Protein to Support Anabolism With Resistance Exercise in Young Men
authors: Phillips SM, Hartman JW, Wilkinson SB
training_status: narrative_review_RT (includes RT trials with milk vs soy etc.)
outcome_types: hypertrophy (lean mass, muscle CSA); strength; acute MPS
intervention_weeks: ~12 weeks in key RT trial (review overall)
notes: Summarises work showing dairy proteins (e.g. milk) can produce greater post-exercise net muscle protein balance and slightly greater 12-week RT hypertrophy than soy when protein is matched.

title: Effects of Different Sources of Dietary Protein on Markers of Kidney Function in Individuals With Diabetes, Prediabetes, and Healthy Persons: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
notes: Across RCTs, higher-protein diets and different protein sources do not meaningfully worsen kidney function over typical study durations in people with or without diabetes.

title: High-Protein Plant-Based Diet Versus a Protein-Matched Omnivorous Diet to Support Resistance Training Adaptations: A Comparison Between Habitual Vegans and Omnivores
outcome_types: body_comp (leg lean mass); muscle CSA; muscle fibre CSA; strength (leg press 1RM)
notes: With ~1.6 g/kg/d protein matched, fully plant-based and omnivorous diets support similar RT-induced gains in muscle mass and strength in young men.

title: A High-Protein Diet With Resistance Exercise Training Improves Weight Loss and Body Composition in Overweight and Obese Patients With Type 2 Diabetes
outcome_types: body_weight; body_comp (FM, FFM); waist_circumference; glycaemic_control; lipids; blood_pressure
notes: Combining a hypocaloric high-protein diet with RT produced the greatest improvements in body composition and cardiometabolic risk markers in adults with T2D.

title: Creatine Supplementation During Resistance Training Does Not Lead to Greater Bone Mineral Density in Older Humans: A Brief Meta-Analysis
authors: Forbes SC; Chilibeck PD; Candow DG
notes: Meta-analysis of RCTs in aging adults doing RT with or without creatine; found no clear additional BMD benefit from creatine beyond RT, with small effects on some bone geometry outcomes.

title: Timing of Creatine Supplementation and Resistance Training: A Brief Review
notes: Brief review (with small quantitative synthesis) on whether pre- vs post-workout creatine timing matters for RT adaptations; overall conclusion is that timing has little practical impact compared with just taking creatine consistently.

title: The Effect of Creatine Supplementation on Markers of Exercise-Induced Muscle Damage: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis of Human Intervention Trials
authors: Northeast J; Clifford T; et al.
intervention_weeks: acute and short-term (single bout to a few weeks)
notes: Systematic review/meta of creatine’s effect on markers of exercise-induced muscle damage and recovery across various exercise modes (RT and others); generally small/moderate protective effects on some damage markers and performance recovery.

title: Creatine Supplementation and Lower Limb Strength Performance: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analyses
authors: Lanhers C; Pereira B; et al.
notes: Meta-analysis showing creatine improves lower-limb strength and power (e.g., leg press, knee extension), particularly with RT programs; includes both short-term and training studies.

title: Impact of Creatine Supplementation and Exercise Training in Older Adults: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
notes: Meta-analysis of creatine plus exercise training in older adults; shows additive benefits for lean mass, strength and some functional tests compared with exercise alone.

title: Creatine Supplementation Protocols With or Without Training Interventions on Body Composition: A GRADE-Assessed Systematic Review and Dose–Response Meta-Analysis
notes: Systematic review/meta examining creatine dosing strategies (with and without structured training) on body composition; dose–response analysis suggests benefits for FFM/lean mass, especially when combined with training.

title: Creatine Supplementation and Upper Limb Strength Performance: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
authors: Lanhers C; Pereira B; et al.
notes: Companion meta-analysis to the lower-limb paper, focused on upper-body strength (bench press, etc.); creatine provides small-to-moderate improvements, especially alongside RT.

title: Effect of Creatine Supplementation on Body Composition and Performance: A Meta-Analysis
notes: Classic early meta-analysis summarising creatine’s impact on body composition and performance in healthy adults; generally positive effects on strength and high-intensity performance with modest lean mass gains.

title: Does Oral Creatine Supplementation Improve Strength? A Meta-Analysis
authors: Dempsey RL; Mazzone MF; Meurer LN
notes: Family-practice oriented meta-analysis of RCTs on creatine and strength; concludes creatine is effective for improving strength in healthy individuals engaged in training.

title: Strategic Creatine Supplementation and Resistance Training in Healthy Older Adults
authors: Candow DG; Vogt E; Johannsmeyer S; Forbes SC; Farthing JP
notes: 12-week RCT in healthy older adults comparing different creatine strategies with RT; creatine + RT improved muscle strength and some body-composition/functional measures versus placebo + RT.

title: Impact of Creatine Supplementation in Combination with Resistance Training on Lean Mass in the Elderly
authors: Pinto CL; Botelho PB; et al.
notes: 12-week double-blind RCT in elderly participants; creatine + RT produced greater gains in lean mass and strength than placebo + RT.

title: Creatine Supplementation During Resistance Training on Lean Tissue Mass and Muscular Strength in Older Adults: A Meta-Analysis
authors: Chilibeck PD; Kaviani M; Candow DG; Zello GA
main_tags: creatine; resistance_training; older_adults; lean_mass; strength; meta_analysis
notes: Meta-analysis focusing on older adults performing RT with or without creatine; concludes creatine + RT meaningfully increases lean tissue mass and upper- and lower-body strength versus RT + placebo.

title: Efficacy of Creatine Supplementation Combined with Resistance Training on Muscle Strength and Muscle Mass in Older Females: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
authors: Dos Santos EEP; de Araújo RC; et al.
notes: Meta-analysis focused specifically on older females; creatine + RT yields greater increases in muscle strength and lean mass than RT alone.

title: Creatine Supplementation for Treating Symptoms of Depression: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
notes: Systematic review/meta looking at creatine as an adjunct for depressive symptoms; populations and interventions are clinical, not RT-focused; primarily relevant for safety/mood, not hypertrophy.

title: Creatine Supplementation and Resistance Training to Preserve Muscle Mass and Attenuate Cancer Progression (CREATINE-52): Study Protocol for a Double-Blind Randomized Controlled Trial
notes: Study protocol only (no outcome data yet) for a 52-week RCT in older adults with colorectal cancer, combining creatine with RT to preserve muscle mass and attenuate cancer progression.

title: Creatine Supplementation and VO2max: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
notes: Meta-analysis of creatine’s effect on VO2max and aerobic performance; effects are generally small and context-dependent; mostly endurance or mixed training, not classic hypertrophy-RT setups.

title: Effects of Creatine Supplementation on the Performance, Physiological Response, and Body Composition Among Swimmers: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis of Randomized Controlled Trials
notes: Meta-analysis in swimmers; creatine improves some sprint/performance outcomes and may modestly affect body composition; training is swimming-specific rather than RT-focused.

title: Efficacy of Creatine Supplementation and Resistance Training on Area and Density of Bone and Muscle in Older Adults
notes: One-year RCT of creatine + whole-body RT vs placebo + RT in older adults; creatine increased tibial bone area and some muscle density measures, with limited effects on bone density at other sites.

title: The Paradoxical Effect of Creatine Monohydrate on Muscle Damage Markers: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
notes: Meta-analysis focusing on blood markers of muscle damage and soreness; finds context-dependent effects (“paradoxical”) where creatine can attenuate or, in some setups, not change markers; includes both RT and other exercise modes.

title: The Additive Effects of Creatine Supplementation and Exercise Training in an Aging Population: A Systematic Review of Randomized Controlled Trials
notes: Systematic review of RCTs in older adults combining creatine with exercise (often RT); overall shows additive benefits on muscle mass, strength and functional outcomes versus training alone.

title: Effectiveness of Creatine in Metabolic Performance: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
notes: Systematic review/meta looking at creatine’s impact on metabolic performance (e.g., glucose, lipids, energy metabolism) and related outcomes; heterogeneous populations and protocols, not specifically RT-focused.

title: Efecto de la suplementación con creatina en la capacidad anaeróbica: un meta-análisis (Effect of Creatine Supplementation in Anaerobic Capacity: A Meta-Analysis)
authors: Quirós-Quirós A; Jiménez-Díaz J; Zamora-Salas JD
notes: Spanish-language meta-analysis on creatine’s effect on anaerobic capacity in healthy subjects (trained and untrained); finds a small-to-moderate positive effect on anaerobic performance.

title: Effect of Creatine Supplementation on Kidney Function: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
notes: Systematic review/meta across RCTs and trials assessing kidney function with creatine use; concludes creatine is generally safe for kidney function in healthy individuals when used at usual doses; useful as safety/background rather than hypertrophy evidence.

title: Creatine Supplementation in Addition to Physical Exercise in the Treatment of Sarcopenia: A Meta-Analysis
notes: Preprint meta-analysis of creatine (often with RT) for sarcopenia; generally supports creatine + exercise improving muscle mass, strength and function in older adults with or at risk of sarcopenia.

title: Creatine Supplementation During Resistance Training in Older Adults: A Meta-Analysis
notes: Found that creatine supplementation during RT in older adults enhances gains in lean mass, strength and some functional outcomes versus RT alone.

title: High-Intensity Resistance Exercise Training to Improve Body Composition and Strength in Older Men With Osteosarcopenia (FrOST)
notes: Community-dwelling older men with osteosarcopenia; 2x/wk high-intensity RT vs non-exercising control, both groups received protein + vitamin D + calcium.

title: Body Composition and Musculoskeletal Health in Older Adults With Obesity and Sarcopenia
notes: Doctoral thesis (University of Manitoba) examining body composition and musculoskeletal health in older adults with obesity and sarcopenia (epidemiology + intervention data).

title: The Effects of Circuit Hydraulic Weight Interval Training on Body Composition and Progression of Resistance in Recreationally Exercising Pre- and Postmenopausal Women
notes: Recreationally active pre- and postmenopausal women completed ~18 weeks of hydraulic circuit RT; whole-body training with progressive resistance.

title: Effects of Soy Milk Ingestion Immediately After Resistance Training on Muscular-Related Biomarkers in Older Men: A Randomized Controlled Trial
notes: Healthy older men; RT 3x/wk for 12 weeks with immediate post-exercise soy milk vs placebo (and on non-training days).

title: The Effects of Resistance Training Programs on Lean Body Mass in Postmenopausal and Elderly Women: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
notes: Systematic review/meta-analysis of RT programs in postmenopausal and elderly women, focusing on lean body mass and functional outcomes.

title: Resistance Training-Induced Gains in Muscle Strength, Body Composition, and Functional Capacity Are Attenuated in Elderly Women With Sarcopenic Obesity
authors: de Oliveira Silva A et al.
notes: Elderly women with and without sarcopenic obesity; 2x/wk RT for 16 weeks; SO group shows blunted improvements in adiposity and functional capacity.

title: The Effects of Resistance Training Volume on Osteosarcopenic Obesity in Older Women
notes: Older women with osteosarcopenic obesity randomized to 1 vs 3 sets per exercise RT; compares volume effects on OSO indices and performance.

title: Effects of Resistance Training on Muscular Strength, Endurance, Body Composition and Functional Performance Among Sarcopenic Patients: A Systematic Review
notes: Looks at RT interventions in sarcopenic older adults and summarises effects on body composition, strength, endurance, and functional tests.

title: Effects of Resistance Training on Sarcopenic Obesity Index in Middle-Aged and Elderly Patients With Sarcopenic Obesity
notes: Middle-aged and older adults with sarcopenic obesity; 16-week RT program vs control; evaluates sarcopenic obesity index and physical performance.

title: Body Composition and Musculoskeletal Health in Older Adults With Obesity and Sarcopenia (Liberty University Thesis)
notes: Master’s thesis (Liberty University) describing relationships between obesity, sarcopenia, and musculoskeletal health in older adults.

title: Effects of Caloric Restriction With or Without Resistance Training in Dynapenic-Overweight and Obese Menopausal Women (MONET Study)
notes: Overweight/obese menopausal women with dynapenia; 6-month caloric restriction ± RT; evaluates body composition, muscle function and cardiometabolic risk.

title: The Effects of Twelve Weeks of Whole-Body Vibration Training and Low-Intensity Resistance Exercise Training on Arterial Function, Muscle Strength, and Physical Performance in Dynapenic Postmenopausal Women
notes: FSU doctoral dissertation; dynapenic postmenopausal women assigned to WBV, low-intensity RT, or control; arterial function and performance outcomes.

title: Plasma Adipokines Levels and Functional Fitness With Concurrent Combined Aerobic and Resistance Training in Older Adults
notes: Doctoral thesis (University of Porto); older adults completed concurrent aerobic+RT; focuses on adipokines and functional fitness changes.

title: Home-Based Resistance Training With Whey Protein Supplementation in Overweight and Obese Adults: Effects on Body Composition and Muscle Strength
notes: Overweight/obese adults performed home-based RT plus whey vs control; examines changes in body composition and strength (Nutrition & Metabolism).

title: Effect of Combined Resistance Training and Protein Supplementation on Muscle Mass and Function in Breast Cancer Survivors
notes: Doctoral dissertation; breast cancer survivors completed RT plus protein supplementation vs control; focus on sarcopenia and functional recovery.

title: Effects of Resistance Training on Body Composition and Function in Older Women With Sarcopenic Obesity (Korean Cohort)
notes: Older Korean women with sarcopenic obesity; ~12 weeks of supervised RT vs control; outcomes include DXA body comp and physical performance tests.

title: Resistance Training and Weight Loss in Older Adults: A Scoping Review
notes: Scoping review mapping RT protocols in weight-loss contexts for overweight and obese older adults, including sarcopenic obesity subgroups.

title: Resistance Training and Whey Protein Supplementation During Energy Restriction in Obese Older Adults: Effects on Body Composition and Functional Performance
notes: Obese older women on hypocaloric diet with RT ± whey; examines preservation of lean mass and functional capacity.

title: Inflammatory Cytokine Responses to Progressive Resistance Training and Fortified Milk in Men Aged 50+ Years: An 18-Month Randomized Controlled Trial
notes: Men ≥50 randomized to PRT + fortified milk vs control (18-month intervention); outcomes include lean mass, strength and inflammatory cytokines.

title: Identification and Characterization of Osteosarcopenic Obesity in Older Adults: Implications for Exercise Interventions
notes: Doctoral thesis testing WBV ± RT in postmenopausal women at risk for osteoporosis; multiple musculoskeletal outcomes.

title: Whole-Body Vibration and Resistance Training in Postmenopausal Women With Low Bone Mass: Effects on Musculoskeletal Health
outcome_types: body_comp; muscle_mass; strength; function; blood_lipids; hemorheology
notes: Middle-aged obese women underwent 12-week RT; examines hypertrophy, functional tests, blood lipids and hemorheological markers.

title: Effects of 12 Weeks of Resistance Training on Body Composition, Muscle Hypertrophy and Function, Blood Lipid Level, and Hemorheological Properties in Middle-Aged Obese Women
notes: Doctoral dissertation on RT as adjunct to cardiac rehabilitation in TAVR patients; focuses on functional recovery and quality of life.

title: Impact of Resistance Training on Recovery and Functional Status in Older Adults Undergoing Transcatheter Aortic Valve Replacement (TAVR)
notes: Thesis examining combined sprint interval training and RT vs single-mode or control in obese older adults.

title: Concurrent Sprint Interval and Resistance Training: Effects on Body Composition, Strength, and Functional Capacity in Obese Older Adults
notes: Systematic review/meta-analysis on RT for secondary sarcopenia (e.g., due to chronic disease, hospitalization) in older adults.

title: Effects of Resistance Training on Older Adults With Secondary Sarcopenia: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
authors: Silva L S L et al.
notes: Scoping review mapping RT prescription variables (volume, intensity, cadence, rest, frequency) in older adults with sarcopenic obesity.

title: Characteristics of Resistance Training-Based Protocols in Older Adults With Sarcopenic Obesity: A Scoping Review
notes: Men ≥50 randomized to PRT + fortified milk vs control (18-month intervention); outcomes include lean mass, strength and inflammatory cytokines.

title: Challenging the American College of Sports Medicine 2009 Position Stand on Resistance Training
main_tags: ACSM_position_stand; resistance_training; critique; loading; volume; exercise_selection; free_weights_vs_machines; exercise_order; rest_periods
outcome_types: conceptual (no primary outcome data; critiques evidence base for RT guidelines)
notes: Critical review arguing that the 2009 ACSM resistance-training position stand misinterprets many studies and selectively cites evidence; claims simple, lower-volume RT may be as effective as complex, periodized, high-volume prescriptions for strength and hypertrophy.

title: Physical Activity and Bone Health (ACSM Position Stand)
authors: Kohrt WM; Bloomfield SA; Little KD; Nelson ME; Yingling VR
main_tags: ACSM_position_stand; physical_activity; bone_health; osteoporosis_prevention; weight_bearing; impact_loading
notes: ACSM position stand outlining how weight-bearing and impact-type physical activity across the lifespan supports bone mass and reduces osteoporosis/fracture risk; provides general dose/type guidelines but not specific RT programming details.

title: A Critical Analysis of the ACSM Position Stand on Resistance Training: Insufficient Evidence to Support Recommended Training Protocols
authors: Carpinelli RN; Otto RM; Winett RA
main_tags: ACSM_position_stand; resistance_training; progression_models; load; sets; frequency; repetition_duration; hypertrophy; strength
notes: Long, detailed critique of the 2002 ACSM “Progression Models in Resistance Training for Healthy Adults” stand; argues that claims about the need for complex progression schemes and high volumes are poorly supported and that low-volume RT can achieve similar adaptations.

title: Exercise and Type 2 Diabetes: The American College of Sports Medicine and the American Diabetes Association: Joint Position Statement
authors: Colberg SR; Sigal RJ; Fernhall B; Regensteiner JG; Blissmer BJ; Rubin RR; Chasan-Taber L; Albright AL; Braun B
main_tags: type2_diabetes; exercise_prescription; physical_activity; aerobic_training; resistance_training; glycaemic_control
outcome_types: glycaemic_control (HbA1c, fasting glucose); cardiometabolic_risk; body_weight; fitness; safety/contraindications
notes: Comprehensive joint statement giving aerobic and resistance-training recommendations for individuals with type 2 diabetes, including intensity/volume guidelines, safety considerations, and adaptations for complications/comorbidities.

title: ACSM Position Stand: The Recommended Quantity and Quality of Exercise for Developing and Maintaining Cardiorespiratory and Muscular Fitness, and Flexibility in Healthy Adults
authors: Pollock ML; Gaesser GA; Butcher JD; Després J-P; Dishman RK; Franklin BA; Garber CE
main_tags: ACSM_position_stand; exercise_prescription; cardiorespiratory_fitness; muscular_fitness; flexibility; healthy_adults
notes: Classic ACSM guideline summarising recommended frequency, intensity, time, and type (FITT) of exercise to develop and maintain cardiorespiratory and muscular fitness and flexibility in healthy adults; includes brief RT recommendations but not detailed progression models.

title: Progression Models in Resistance Training for Healthy Adults (ACSM Position Stand)
authors: Kraemer WJ; Adams K; Cafarelli E; Dudley GA; Dooly C; Feigenbaum MS; Fleck SJ; Franklin B; Fry AC; Hoffman JR; Newton RU; Potteiger J; Ratamess NA; et al.
main_tags: resistance_training; progression_models; load; volume; frequency; periodization; sets; repetition_range; rest_intervals; healthy_adults
outcome_types: hypothetical training_effects (strength; hypertrophy; power; endurance – guidance only)
notes: Key ACSM RT position stand outlining progression models for novice, intermediate, advanced, and elite healthy adults; recommends multi-set training, specific %1RM/repetition ranges, periodized progression, and higher volumes/frequencies for advanced trainees—this is the document critiqued by Carpinelli (110, 108).

title: Physical Activity and Public Health in Older Adults: Recommendation from the American College of Sports Medicine and the American Heart Association
authors: Nelson ME; Rejeski WJ; Blair SN; Duncan PW; Judge JO; King AC; Macera CA; Castaneda-Sceppa C
main_tags: older_adults; physical_activity; public_health; ACSM_position; AHA_recommendation; aerobic_training; resistance_training; balance_training
outcome_types: physical_activity_guidelines (aerobic volume; RT; balance/flexibility); health_outcomes (falls, disability, chronic_disease risk)
notes: ACSM/AHA recommendation paper translating PA guidelines specifically for older adults; provides targets for aerobic activity plus resistance and flexibility/balance training to maintain function, reduce falls, and manage chronic disease risk.

title: Resistance Training for Older Women: Do Adaptive Responses Support the ACSM and NSCA Position Stands?
authors: Cavalcante EF; Kassiano W; Ribeiro AS; Costa B; Cyrino LT; Cunha PM; Antunes M; dos Santos L; Tomeleri CM; Nabuco HCG; Sugihara-Junior P; Fernandes RR; Rodrigues RJ; Carneiro MAS; et al.
main_tags: older_women; resistance_training; training_intensity; ACSM_position_stand; NSCA_position_stand; hypertrophy; strength; metabolic_health
outcome_types: muscle_mass (SMM, lean_mass); strength (1RM, dynamic); physical_performance; metabolic_biomarkers
notes: 12-week RT trial in 101 older women using different load/intensity prescriptions to test whether observed adaptations align with ACSM/NSCA position stand recommendations for this population; examines strength, skeletal muscle mass, functional performance, and metabolic markers.
